body: @blizzz what do you think? we shoudn't block access for users without display name

@jerrac owncloud 5?

one of the nice things is that system accounts like "krbtgt" don't show up ;) on the other hand they can be filtered out with proper ldap filters, but as we know must owncloud admins don't know how to set them up. 

so far i thought a human user will have a display name. 

also, if a display name is not found this will be logged in the info level.

let us say we allow log ins without a display name, we need to have a fall back. the most reasonable feature would be what is used as internal username which is by default the object's uuid. it looks like this: 
78cd1cdc-5cc3-1032-8f68-2ffe50639415 

i have some doubts about the user experience. if the setting would have been changed to uid/samaccoutname/cd before going into production, it's a different thing. but the default would not lead to good results. 

we could have additional log entries for when a login fails of course.

@blizzz yes, owncloud 5.

i have no problems with blocking users who don't have a display name. if i set that in my ldap settings, then that means i expect all my users to have one. so it's reasonable to not allow users who don't have one.

also, a fall back would be either ugly, or might let information out that admins would rather not let out. i don't want my users usernames being displayed anywhere, if the username attribute was the fall back, that would expose it.

my prefered solution would be an error message displayed to the user along the lines "you account is missing critical information. give your system admin this error id so that he can find out what's wrong." then the log message would have the error id and a message telling me exactly what's wrong with their ldap entry.

when i first encountered this, i went through a lot of troubleshooting under the assumption something was wrong with the users username or password. since that's the error they were getting. an error/log combination like i described would have saved a lot of time. :)

side note: i still don't like using the guid attributes as the uuid for owncloud. when moving an ldap entry in novell edirectory, i have to delete the old entry, and then recreate it in it's new ou. that means the guid changes. thus, their access to their owncloud files would be broken. their username attribute is far more likely to stay the same, and if it changes, it would be much easier to move the owncloud files around based on that, than on making sure to save the guid before i delete an old entry...

> my prefered solution would be an error message displayed to the user along the lines "you account is missing critical information. give your system admin this error id so that he can find out what's wrong." then the log message would have the error id and a message telling me exactly what's wrong with their ldap entry.

cannot be done for oc 6 anymore, oc 7 only. atm, the user backends only can say whether a login was successful or not, it would require deeper changes and is rather an enhancement. this could go on the roadmap for 7.

meanwhile, i.e. for 6, we can add extra log messages for failed logins, if it is of help.

> i still don't like using the guid attributes as the uuid for owncloud. when moving an ldap entry in novell edirectory, i have to delete the old entry, and then recreate it in it's new ou. that means the guid changes.

actually, the point is that the uuid of the object persists. i am not familiar with novell edirectory but the guid was what was found out using the bug tracker ;) is there a better attribute that returns a persistent uuid in novell edirectory?

at least it's on the map. :) my report was more for other peoples benefit, since i already figured it out.

my point was that the uuid of the ldap entries does **not** persist. at least in novell edirectory. **if** i recall correctly, you can't manipulate the guid attribute, so you can't save the old guid for use in the new ldap entry. this is only an issue if you are moving your ldap entries between ou's like our system does. since edir is odd and doesn't support moving entries between ou's...

> my point was that the uuid of the ldap entries does not persist. at least in novell edirectory.

that's why i asked you whether you know an attribute in novell edirectory that provides a permanent identifier?

@blizzz 
> that's why i asked you whether you know an attribute in novell edirectory that provides a permanent identifier?
which is the guid as far as i can tell. and, as far as i can tell, you can't modify it. this is what i get in apache directory studio when i try to edit it.
![novellguid](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/910764/1552107/c8f8b1c2-4e1e-11e3-945b-f2136f3b2849.png)

and, when i've tried to use novell's own tools to move an entry, it can't.

um, this seems a bit off topic, should we continue in a different issue, or via the forums, or something?
